column2: THE PERUVIAN COLONY.

column2: If we look at the map of Atlantis, as revealed by the deep sea soundings, we will find that it approaches at one point, by its connecting ridge, quite closely to the shore of South America, above the mouth of the Amazon, and that probably it was originally connected with it.
column3: If we look at the map of Atlantis, as revealed by the deep sea soundings, we will find that it approaches at one point, by its connecting ridge, quite closely to the shore of South America, above the mouth of the Amazon, and that probably it was originally connected with it.

column2: If the population of Atlantis expanded westwardly, it naturally found its way in its ships up the magnificent valley of the Amazon and its tributaries; and, passing by the low and fever-stricken lands of Brazil, it rested not until it had reached the high, fertile, beautiful, and healthful regions of Bolivia, from which it would eventually cross the mountains into Peru.
column3: If the population of Atlantis expanded westwardly, it naturally found its way in its ships up the magnificent valley of the Amazon and its tributaries; and, passing by the low and fever stricken lands of Brazil, it rested not until it had reached the high, fertile, beautiful, and healthful regions of Bolivia, from which it would eventually cross the mountains into Peru.

column2: Here it would establish its outlying colonies at the terminus of its western line of advance, arrested only by the Pacific Ocean, precisely as we have seen it advancing up the valley of the Mississippi, and carrying on its mining operations on the shores of Lake Superior; precisely as we have seen it going eastward up the Mediterranean, past the Dardanelles, and founding Aryan, Hamitic, and probably Turanian colonies on the farther shores of the Black Sea and on the Caspian.

column2: Montesino tells us that at some time near the date of the Deluge, in other words, in the highest antiquity, America was invaded by a people with four leaders, named Ayar-manco-topa, Ayar-chaki, Ayar-aucca, and Ayar-uyssu.

column2: The Quichuas--this invading people--were originally a fair skinned race, with blue eyes and light and even auburn hair; they had regular features, large heads, and large bodies.
column3: The Quichuas-this invading people-were originally a fair skinned race, with blue eyes and light and even auburn hair; they had regular features, large heads, and large bodies.

column3: Their descendants are to this day an olive skinned people, much lighter in color than the Indian tribes subjugated by them.

column2: They were a great race.
column3: They were a great race.

column2: Peru, as it was known to the Spaniards, held very much the same relation to the ancient Quichua civilization as England in the sixteenth century held to the civilization of the empire of the Caesars.
column3: Peru, as it was known to the Spaniards, held very much the same relation to the ancient Quichua civilization as England in the sixteenth century held to the civilization of the empire of the Caesars.

column2: The Incas were simply an offshoot, who, descending from the mountains, subdued the rude races of the sea-coast, and imposed their ancient civilization upon them.

column2: The Quichua nation extended at one time over a region of country more than two thousand miles long.
column3: The Quichua nation extended at one time over a region of country more than two thousand miles long.

column2: This whole region, when the Spaniards arrived, "was a populous and prosperous empire, complete in its civil organization, supported by an efficient system of industry, and presenting a notable development of some of the more important arts of civilized life." (Baldwin's "Ancient America," p. 222.)

column2: Cieca de Leon mentions "great edifices" that were in ruins at Tiahuanaca, "an artificial hill raised on a groundwork of stone," and "two stone idols, apparently made by skilful artificers," ten or twelve feet high, clothed in long robes.

column2: The Peruvians made large use of aqueducts, which they built with notable skill, using hewn stones and cement, and making them very substantial. One extended four hundred and fifty miles across sierras and over rivers.

column2: The public roads of the Peruvians were most remarkable; they were built on masonry.
column3: The public roads of the Peruvians were most remarkable; they were built on masonry.

column2: One of these roads ran along the mountains through the whole length of the empire, from Quito to Chili; another, starting from this at Cuzco, went down to the coast, and extended northward to the equator.
column3: One of these roads ran along the mountains through the whole length of the empire, from Quito to Chili; another, starting from this at Cuzco, went down to the coast, and extended northward to the equator.

column2: These roads were from twenty to twenty-five feet wide, were macadamized with pulverized stone mixed with lime and bituminous cement, and were walled in by strong walls "more than a fathom in thickness." In many places these roads were cut for leagues through the rock; great ravines were filled up with solid masonry; rivers were crossed by suspension bridges, used here ages before their introduction into Europe.
column3: These roads were from twenty to twenty five feet wide, were macadamized with pulverized stone mixed with lime and bituminous cement, and were walled in by strong walls "more than a fathom in thickness." In many places these roads were cut for leagues through the rock; great ravines were filled up with solid masonry; rivers were crossed by suspension bridges, used here ages before their introduction into Europe.

column2: Says Baldwin, "The builders of our Pacific Railroad, with their superior engineering skill and mechanical appliances, might reasonably shrink from the cost and the difficulties of such a work as this. Extending from one degree north of Quito to Cuzco, and from Cuzco to Chili, it was quite as long as the two Pacific railroads, and its wild route among the mountains was far more difficult." Sarmiento, describing it, said, "It seems to me that if the emperor (Charles V.) should see fit to order the construction of another road like that which leads from Quito to Cuzco, or that which from Cuzco goes toward Chili, I certainly think he would not be able to make it, with all his power." Humboldt said, "This road was marvellous; none of the Roman roads I had seen in Italy, in the south of France, or in Spain, appeared to me more imposing than this work of the ancient Peruvians."

column2: I have already shown, in the chapter upon the similarities between the civilizations of the Old and New Worlds, some of the remarkable coincidences which existed between the Peruvians and the ancient European races; I will again briefly, refer to a few of them:

one.

column2: They worshipped the sun, moon, and planets.
column3: They worshipped the sun, moon, and planets.
two.

column2: They believed in the immortality of the soul.
column3: They believed in the immortality of the soul.
three.

column2: They believed in the resurrection of the body, and accordingly embalmed their dead.
column3: They believed in the resurrection of the body, and accordingly embalmed their dead.
four.

column2: The priest examined the entrails of the animals offered in sacrifice, and, like the Roman augurs, divined the future from their appearance.
column3: The priest examined the entrails of the animals offered in sacrifice, and, like the Roman augurs, divined the future from their appearance.
five.

column2: They had an order of women vowed to celibacy--vestal virgins-nuns; and a violation of their vow was punished, in both continents, by their being buried alive.
column3: They had an order of women vowed to celibacy-vestal virgins nuns; and a violation of their vow was punished, in both continents, by their being buried alive.
six.

column2: They divided the year into twelve months.
column3: They divided the year into twelve months.
seven.

column2: Their enumeration was by tens; the people were divided into decades and hundreds, like the Anglo-Saxons; and the whole nation into bodies of 500, 1000, and 10,000, with a governor over each.
column3: Their enumeration was by tens; the people were divided into decades and hundreds, like the Anglo Saxons; and the whole nation into bodies of five hundred, one thousand, and ten thousand, with a governor over each.
eight.

column2: They possessed castes; and the trade of the father descended to the son, as in India.
column3: They possessed castes; and the trade of the father descended to the son, as in India.
nine.

column2: They had bards and minstrels, who sung at the great festivals.
column3: They had bards and minstrels, who sung at the great festivals.
ten.

column2: Their weapons were the same as those of the Old World, and made after the same pattern.
column3: Their weapons were the same as those of the Old World, and made after the same pattern.
eleven.

column2: They drank toasts and invoked blessings.
column3: They drank toasts and invoked blessings.
twelve.

column2: They built triumphal arches for their returning heroes, and strewed the road before them with leaves and flowers.
column3: They built triumphal arches for their returning heroes, and strewed the road before them with leaves and flowers.
thirteen.

column2: They used sedan-chairs.
column3: They used sedan chairs.
fourteen.

column2: They regarded agriculture as the principal interest of the nation, and held great agricultural fairs and festivals for the interchange of the productions of the farmers.
column3: They regarded agriculture as the principal interest of the nation, and held great agricultural fairs and festivals for the interchange of the productions of the farmers.

column2: The king opened the agricultural season by a great celebration, and, like the kings of Egypt, he put his hand to the plough, and ploughed the first furrow.
column3: The king opened the agricultural season by a great celebration, and, like the kings of Egypt, he put his hand to the plough, and ploughed the first furrow.
sixteen.

column2: I might pursue those parallels much farther; but it seems to me that these extraordinary coincidences must have arisen either from identity of origin or long-continued ancient intercourse.
column3: I might pursue those parallels much farther; but it seems to me that these extraordinary coincidences must have arisen either from identity of origin or long continued ancient intercourse.

column2: There can be little doubt that a fair-skinned, light-haired, bearded race, holding the religion which Plato says prevailed in Atlantis, carried an Atlantean civilization at an early day up the valley of the Amazon to the heights of Bolivia and Peru, precisely as a similar emigration of Aryans went westward to the shores of the Mediterranean and Caspian, and it is very likely that these diverse migrations habitually spoke the same language.
column3: There can be little doubt that a fair skinned, light haired, bearded race, holding the religion which Plato says prevailed in Atlantis, carried an Atlantean civilization at an early day up the valley of the Amazon to the heights of Bolivia and Peru, precisely as a similar emigration of Aryans went westward to the shores of the Mediterranean and Caspian, and it is very likely that these diverse migrations habitually spoke the same language.

column2: Senor Vincente Lopez, a Spanish gentleman of Montevideo, in 1872 published a work entitled "Les Races Aryennes in Perou," in which he attempts to prove that the great Quichua language, which the Incas imposed on their subjects over a vast extent of territory, and which is still a living tongue in Peru and Bolivia, is really a branch of the great Aryan or Indo-European speech.
column3: Senor Vincente Lopez, a Spanish gentleman of Montevideo, in eighteen seventy two published a work entitled "Les Races Aryennes in Perou," in which he attempts to prove that the great Quichua language, which the Incas imposed on their subjects over a vast extent of territory, and which is still a living tongue in Peru and Bolivia, is really a branch of the great Aryan or Indo European speech.

column2: Senor Lopez's view, that the Peruvians were Aryans who left the parent stock long before the Teutonic or Hellenic races entered Europe, is supported by arguments drawn from language, from the traces of institutions, from religious beliefs, from legendary records, and artistic remains.	Senor Lopez's view, that the Peruvians were Aryans who left the parent stock long before the Teutonic or Hellenic races entered Europe, is supported by arguments drawn from language, from the traces of institutions, from religious beliefs, from legendary records, and artistic remains.
column3: true

column2: The evidence from language is treated scientifically, and not as a kind of ingenious guessing.
column3: The evidence from language is treated scientifically, and not as a kind of ingenious guessing.

column2: Senor Lopez first combats the idea that the living dialect of Peru is barbarous and fluctuating.
column3: Senor Lopez first combats the idea that the living dialect of Peru is barbarous and fluctuating.

column2: It is not one of the casual and shifting forms of speech produced by nomad races.
column3: It is not one of the casual and shifting forms of speech produced by nomad races.

column2: To which of the stages of language does this belong--the agglutinative, in which one root is fastened on to another, and a word is formed in which the constitutive elements are obviously distinct, or the inflexional, where the auxiliary roots get worn down and are only distinguishable by the philologist?
column3: To which of the stages of language does this belong-the agglutinative, in which one root is fastened on to another, and a word is formed in which the constitutive elements are obviously distinct, or the inflexional, where the auxiliary roots get worn down and are only distinguishable by the philologist?

column2: As all known Aryan tongues are inflexional, Senor Lopez may appear to contradict himself when he says that Quichua is an agglutinative Aryan language.
column3: As all known Aryan tongues are inflexional, Senor Lopez may appear to contradict himself when he says that Quichua is an agglutinative Aryan language.

column2: But he quotes Mr. Max Mueller's opinion that there must have been a time when the germs of Aryan tongues had not yet reached the inflexional stage, and shows that while the form of Quichua is agglutinative, as in Turanian, the roots of words are Aryan.
column3: But he quotes mr Max Mueller's opinion that there must have been a time when the germs of Aryan tongues had not yet reached the inflexional stage, and shows that while the form of Quichua is agglutinative, as in Turanian, the roots of words are Aryan.

column2: If this be so, Quichua may be a linguistic missing link.
column3: If this be so, Quichua may be a linguistic missing link.

column2: When we first look at Quichua, with its multitude of words, beginning with hu, and its great preponderance of q's, it seems almost as odd as Mexican. column2: But many of these forms are due to a scanty alphabet, and really express familiar sounds; and many, again, result from the casual spelling of the Spaniards.
column3: But many of these forms are due to a scanty alphabet, and really express familiar sounds; and many, again, result from the casual spelling of the Spaniards.

column2: We must now examine some of the forms which Aryan roots are supposed to take in Quichua.
column3: We must now examine some of the forms which Aryan roots are supposed to take in Quichua.

column2: In the first place, Quichua abhors the shock of two consonants.
column3: In the first place, Quichua abhors the shock of two consonants.

column2: Thus, a word like ple'w in Greek would be unpleasant to the Peruvian's ear, and he says pillui, 'I sail.' The plu, again, in pluma, a feather, is said to be found in pillu, 'to fly.' Quichua has no v, any more than Greek has, and just as the Greeks had to spell Roman words beginning with V with Ou, like Valerius--Ou?ale'rios--so, where Sanscrit has v, Quichua has sometimes hu.

column2: Thus there are the Caribs, whose name may have the same origin as that of our old friends the Carians, and mean the Braves, and their land the home of the Braves, like Kaleva-la, in Finnish.

column2: Again, Quichua has an 'alpha privative'--thus A-stani means 'I change a thing's place;' for ni or mi is the first person singular, and, added to the root of a verb, is the sign of the first person of the present indicative.

column2: For instance, can means being, and Can-mi, or Cani, is 'I am.' In the same way Munanmi, or Munani, is 'I love,' and Apanmi, or Apani, 'I carry.' So Lord Strangford was wrong when he supposed that the last verb in mi lived with the last patriot in Lithuania.

column2: Peru has stores of a grammatical form which has happily perished in Europe.
column3: Peru has stores of a grammatical form which has happily perished in Europe.

column2: It is impossible to do more than refer to the supposed Aryan roots contained in the glossary, but it may be noticed that the future of the Quichuan verb is formed in s--I love, Munani; I shall love, Munasa--and that the affixes denoting cases in the noun are curiously like the Greek prepositions."

column2: The resemblance between the Quichua and Mandan words for I or me--mi--will here be observed.

column2: Very recently Dr. Rudolf Falb has announced (Neue Freie Presse, of Vienna) that he has discovered that the relation of the Quichua and Aimara languages to the Aryan and Semitic tongues is very close; that, in fact, they "exhibit the most astounding affinities with the Semitic tongue, and particularly the Arabic," in which tongue Dr. Falb has been skilled from his boyhood.
column3: Very recently dr Rudolf Falb has announced (Neue Freie Presse, of Vienna) that he has discovered that the relation of the Quichua and Aimara languages to the Aryan and Semitic tongues is very close; that, in fact, they "exhibit the most astounding affinities with the Semitic tongue, and particularly the Arabic," in which tongue dr Falb has been skilled from his boyhood.

column2: Following up the lines of this discovery, Dr. Falb has found (1) a connecting link with the Aryan roots, and (2) has ultimately arrived face to face with the surprising revelation that "the Semitic roots are universally Aryan." The common stems of all the variants are found in their purest condition in Quichua and Aimara, from which fact Dr. Falb derives the conclusion that the high plains of Peru and Bolivia must be regarded as the point of exit of the present human race.
column3: Following up the lines of this discovery, dr Falb has found (one) a connecting link with the Aryan roots, and (two) has ultimately arrived face to face with the surprising revelation that "the Semitic roots are universally Aryan." The common stems of all the variants are found in their purest condition in Quichua and Aimara, from which fact dr Falb derives the conclusion that the high plains of Peru and Bolivia must be regarded as the point of exit of the present human race.

column2: [Since the above was written I have received a letter from Dr. Falb, dated Leipsic, April 5th, 1881.
column3: [Since the above was written I have received a letter from dr Falb, dated Leipsic, april fifth eighteen eighty one.

column2: Scholars will be glad to learn that Dr. Falb's great work on the relationship of the Aryan and Semitic languages to the Quichua and Aimara tongues will be published in a year or two; the manuscript contains over two thousand pages, and Dr. Falb has devoted to it ten years of study.
column3: Scholars will be glad to learn that dr Falb's great work on the relationship of the Aryan and Semitic languages to the Quichua and Aimara tongues will be published in a year or two; the manuscript contains over two thousand pages, and dr Falb has devoted to it ten years of study.

column2: A work from such a source, upon so curious and important a subject, will be looked for with great interest.]

column2: But it is impossible that the Quichuas and Aimaras could have passed across the wide Atlantic to Europe if there had been no stepping-stone in the shape of Atlantis with its bridge-like ridges connecting the two continents.
column3: But it is impossible that the Quichuas and Aimaras could have passed across the wide Atlantic to Europe if there had been no stepping stone in the shape of Atlantis with its bridge like ridges connecting the two continents.

column2: It is, however, more reasonable to suppose that the Quichuas and Aimaras were a race of emigrants from Plato's island than to think that Atlantis was populated from South America.
column3: It is, however, more reasonable to suppose that the Quichuas and Aimaras were a race of emigrants from Plato's island than to think that Atlantis was populated from South America.

column2: The very traditions to which we have referred as existing among the Peruvians, that the civilized race were white and bearded, and that they entered or invaded the country, would show that civilization did not originate in Peru, but was a transplantation from abroad, and only in the direction of Atlantis can we look for a white and bearded race.
column3: The very traditions to which we have referred as existing among the Peruvians, that the civilized race were white and bearded, and that they entered or invaded the country, would show that civilization did not originate in Peru, but was a transplantation from abroad, and only in the direction of Atlantis can we look for a white and bearded race.

column2: In fact, kindred races, with the same arts, and speaking the same tongue in an early age of the world, separated in Atlantis and went east and west--the one to repeat the civilization of the mother-country along the shores of the Mediterranean Sea, which, like a great river, may be said to flow out from the Black Sea, with the Nile as one of its tributaries, and along the shores of the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf; while the other emigration advanced up the Amazon, and created mighty nations upon its head-waters in the valleys of the Andes and on the shores of the Pacific.
column3: In fact, kindred races, with the same arts, and speaking the same tongue in an early age of the world, separated in Atlantis and went east and west-the one to repeat the civilization of the mother country along the shores of the Mediterranean Sea, which, like a great river, may be said to flow out from the Black Sea, with the Nile as one of its tributaries, and along the shores of the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf; while the other emigration advanced up the Amazon, and created mighty nations upon its head waters in the valleys of the Andes and on the shores of the Pacific.
